title-group.article-title: The influence of montmorillonite modification on the properties of composite material based on poly(methacrylic acid)

abstract.p: In this work a new class of functional composites was prepared based on the organically modificated montmorillonite and methacrylic acid. In the first step, the native montmorillonite was mixed with poly(ethylenimine) monomer to promote the intercalation process. In the second step, the methacrylic acid and initiator (potassium persulfate) were added and polymerization was carried out at 80°C for 2 hours. Characterization of the obtained composite material was performed by Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy. The change in interlamellar spacing of montmorillonite after polymer composite preparation was determined by X-ray diffraction. In prepared composite samples the existence of two crystalline phases was estimated by X-ray measurements. In the first, the poly(methacrylic acid) chains are intercalated within the montmorillonite layers, and in the second, they are dispersed in the polymer matrix. The influence of montmorillonite on the thermal properties of the obtained composites was measured using the combined thermogravimetry and differential scanning calorimetry method. The porosity of the prepared samples was determined by isotherm adsorption and the desorption of nitrogen (Brunauer–Emmett–Teller method). It was assessed that a certain amount of polymer is deposited on the montmorillonite and thus covering of the micropores and partially covering of the mesopores was achieved.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Polymer–clay composites offer a tremendous improvement in a wide range of physical and engineering properties for polymers with low filler loading. Many kinds of clay minerals, such as montmorillonite, kaoline, talc, mica, etc., have been used as inorganic fillers for the conventional polymer composites to low cost or to give them special properties, such as modulus, hardness, thermal stability, electrical insulation, thickening, opacity and brightness, etc.1,2 The studies on the interaction between clay minerals and organic compounds have been conducted from the beginning of the 20th century, increasing in number and in topics.3 The research of intercalation of organic molecules into the interlayer space of clay minerals started in the 1920s, after the introduction of X-ray diffraction in 1913.4 One of the earliest papers was from Smith5 in 1934 on interactions with nicotine. Polymer–nanoclay nanocomposites were firstly invented at Toyota Central R&D Labs.6,7 Since then, extensive worldwide research on polymer–clay composites has been conducted in industry and academia. Presently, development has widened into almost every engineering polymer, including polypropylene,8 polyethylene, polystyrene, polyvinylchloride, acrylonitrile butadiene styrene polymer, polymethylmethacrylate, polyethyleneterephthalate, polyacrylonitrile, polycarbonate, polyethylene oxide, epoxy resin, polyimide, polylactide, polycaprolactone, poly p-phenylene vinylene, polypyrole, rubber, starch, polyurethane and polyvinylpyridine.9–11 The preparation of polymer–clay composites offers a route to new materials with predefined structure and performance;12 thus, the clays are a common class of fillers for polymer composite preparation in industry. The efficiency of clays modifies many different properties of the polymer, such as sorbancy, ion exchange capabilities and thermal and solvent resistance. They give improved mechanical properties and accelerated diffusion of oxygen,13 which is important for the packaging industry. Grafting of some functional polymers to the surface of clay minerals can improve the interaction between the polymeric matrix and fillers.12 To reduce costs and improve the comprehensive water absorbing properties of superabsorbent materials based on acrylic monomers, grafting acrylic monomers onto clay and fabricating a composite consisting of a polymer and clay is a priority.14 Nanocomposite polymer–clay represents a combination of structural, physical and chemical properties of both clay and polymer, where one component has nanometric dimensions. The wide and diversified use of layered silicates (especially clays) is due to the negative charge of its layers. In smectite clays (type 2:1) there is an octahedral layer in a sandwich between two tetrahedral layers. The Si4+ cations in the tetrahedral layer and the Al3+ cations in the octahedral layer can be isomorphously substituted by the lower valence cations. Thus, a permanently negative charge is created in the layered structure, which is compensated by hydrated cations Na+, Ca+, K+, in the intermediate space, readily exchangeable in the water medium. Since the early work, there has been growing interest in the investigation of properties of complexes of organic molecules with smectite silicate mineral montmorillonite.4,8 Polymerically modified layered silicates are an important component for an effective route to nanocomposite preparation.15 Traditional methods to modify the clay are usually limited to small organic cations, preferably containing long alkyl chain(s), which are exchanged with the inorganic cations in the clay gallery. Carrado and Komadel16 studied acid activation of montmorillonites for polymer–clay nanocomposite preparation. The hydrophilic nature of the clay surface allows a homogenous dispersion in the organic polymer matrix.17,18 Montmorillonite, for example, has several advantages for use as a support, including its lack of toxicity, chemical reactivity and hydrophilicity, allowing easy fixation of biomolecules.19 Montmorillonite with poly(methacrylic acid) can be used as a settling inhibiting agent in the dye preparation process. Montmorillonite with polymer is soaked in solvent to swell, and in that state it is added to the mixture of polymer binder, solvent, pigments and other additives to prevent coagulation. Shen et al.20 obtained organic–inorganic hybrid nanocomposite materials of poly(methylmethacrylate) (PMMA) and organically modified silicate systems via melt intercalation with variation of tacticity and molecular weight as the main molecular variables. The organic cations lower the surface energy of the montmorillonite surface and improve wetting with the polymer matrix.21 Moreover, the long organic chains of such surfactants, with positively charged NH2+ groups, are tethered to the surface of the negatively charged silicate layers, resulting in an increase of the gallery height.22 It then becomes possible for organic species (monomers or prepolymers) to diffuse between the layers and eventually separate them. Sometimes, the alkylammonium cations may even provide functional groups that can react with the polymer or initiate polymerization of monomers.23 The microchemical environment in the galleries is, therefore, appropriate to the intercalation of monomer molecules. Conclusively, the surface modification both increases the basal spacing of clays and serves as a compatibilizer between the hydrophilic clay and the hydrophobic polymer.24 Inorganic–organic host–guest materials based upon layered clay minerals, such as montmorillonite, provide opportunities to investigate reactions both on the surface and within the intergallery regions of these clay hosts. The aim of this study was the preparation of the polymerically modified clays, and the fabrication of their polymer composites. Commercially available poly(ethylenimine) (PEI) with a molecular weight (MW) of 60000, as the polycation, was used for montmorillonite clay particle modifications. Organically modified clay particles were used for composite preparation with methacrylic acid (MAA) by free radical addition polymerization. Composites of poly(methacrylic acid) and montmorillonite (treated with cationic organo-surfactant) were prepared by a two-step procedure. The main goal was to estimate the thermal properties of the obtained material.

sec.title: Reagents
sec.p: MAA (purity 98%) was supplied from Fluka, Sigma-Aldrich, Steinheim, Germany. Potassium persulfate (K2S2O8; purity 99%) was supplied from Riedel-de Haën, Seelze, Germany. PEI was supplied as a 50 wt% water solution from Sigma, St. Louis, MO. It was declared as a branched polymer with Mn = 60000 g/mol. The clay mineral was montmorillonite, supplied from Mineralica, Vranjska Banja, origin Prisjan, Republic Serbia.

sec.title: Composite preparation
sec.p:
In the first step 10 g of montmorillonite was mixed with 50 ml of water in a glass vessel, and was added to the mixture of 2 g of 50 wt% water solution of PEI, 2 ml of concentrated HCl and 7 ml of MAA. The suspension was mixed for 1 hour with a hot plate magnetic stirrer (at 40 °C) in order to promote the separation of the montmorillonite layers by the PEI chain, whose links have a positive charge at nitrogen atoms due to the presence of HCl. The defined ratio of Cl− to N+ atoms in PEI (1:1) was used to make polycation, the structure of which is given in the Figure 1. Penetration of the monomer molecules between the montmorillonite layers was performed for 60 minutes. Then, 50 mg of potassium persulfate, K2S2O8, was added, and the temperature was set up at 80°C. The polymerization was carried out for 2 hours with constant stirring. There occurred grafting polymerization on the montmorillonite surface.23 At the end the obtained composites were filtered through a Buchner funnel, rinsed with water and dried at 80°C. Figure 1.
Polycation formed in the reaction of poly(ethylenimine) and HCl in water.

sec.title: Characterization of composites
sec.p: Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) analysis of the obtained samples was done by a Bomem Hartmann & Braun MB-series spectrometer. Samples were milled with KBr (0.5 mg of the composite with 150 mg of KBr) and formed tablets under vacuum press. Recording was performed in wave bands ranging from 400 to 4000 cm−1.

Thermogravimetric analysis was carried out by a thermogravimetric analyser (SDT Q600 V8.3 Build 101, TA Instruments) under nitrogen atmosphere in temperature ranging from 20 to 350°C. The heating rate was 10°C/min.

X-ray measurements were conducted on specimens cut from the moulded samples to examine the interlayer activity in the prepared composite using a Phillips PW1350 X-ray generator equipped with a nickel-filtered Cu Kα (λ = 1.5418 Å). The diffractograms were recorded in the 2θ range from 5 to 60° at 25°C. Data analysis, including intensity integration, background correction and Lorentz transformation, were performed with the STORE XRED program package.

The porosity of the prepared samples was determined by isotherm adsorption and desorption of nitrogen (Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) method). The specific surface of the samples, SBET (m2/g), was calculated based on the adsorption measurement data. The total pores volume (V0.99) was calculated according to the Gurvitsch method. The total micropores volume (Vmic) of the tested samples was determined according to the Dubinin–Radushkevich equation.

sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p:
This work concerned the preparation of an organically modified montmorillonite–poly(methacrylic acid) composite and investigation of its thermal properties. The final form of the obtained composites was a yellowish powder. Figures 2 and 3 show the FTIR spectra of the unmodified filler montmorillonite and composites, respectively. The differences in FTIR spectra confirm (peak at 1721 cm−1 originating from polymer C=O valence vibrations, which is not present in pure montmorillonite) that there occurred incorporation of polymer material into montmorillonite layers. For montmorillonite, a band is observed at 1632 cm−1 originating from the H-O-H bending vibrations. The typical wide band at 1045 cm−1, originating from Si-O-Si stretching vibrations, was also detected (Table 1). The OH stretching vibrations, within the mineral smectite phase, give a characteristic band at 3624 cm−1 for the montmorillonite sample, which originated from various hydroxyl groups in smectite: Al-OH-Al, Al-OH-Mg, Al-OH-Fe. The observed wide band at wavelength 3434 cm−1 corresponds to H-O-H stretching vibrations originating from the adsorbed water in the space between the layers.25 The band originating from the Si-O-Al bond bending vibrations occurs at 522 cm−1. In the montmorillonite sample there appears a band at 798 cm−1, followed by a lesser intensity band at 779 cm−1, which is, according to the reference data,26–28 a quartz doublet. The band at wavelength 683 cm−1 is characteristic for Si-O-Si bending vibrations in montmorillonite, and the band at 470 cm−1 originates from the Si-O-Si bending bond. For the obtained samples, bands from both montmorillonite and organic compounds appeared in recorded FTIR spectrum. The band at 1721 cm−1 originates from C=O stretching, at 1297 cm−1 from C-O stretching and at 1453 cm−1 from C-H vibrations of poly(methacrylic acid). Figure 2.
Fourier transform infrared spectrum of unmodified montmorillonite. Figure 3.
Fourier transform infrared spectrum of the obtained composite based on organically modified montmorillonite and poly(methacrylic acid).

X-ray diffraction data may be used to yield insight into the nature of inorganic–organic reactions involving layered clays, such as montmorillonite. If the organic monomer intercalates into the intergallery regions of the host, where subsequent polymerization may be initiated, a measurable change in the spacing between the layers generally occurs. In Figure 4 are given the X-ray diffraction of the montmorillonite and composite. For the obtained composite material, new reflexion planes appeared in diffractograms in the region from 27 to 29°. Rentgeno-diffractional analysis of the composite samples revealed the presence of different crystalline phases. The prevalent forms mineral is smectite (S), followed by quartz (Q), opal (O) and feldspar (F).29,30 Beside these crystalline phases there is present an amorphous phase. Figure 4.
X-Ray diffraction of unmodified montmorillonite (1) and its poly(methylmethacrylate) composite (2). S: smectite, Q: quartz, O: opal, F: feldspar.

The thermogravimetry (TG) curves indicate a slower loss of mass in the composite sample (6.806% at 173.14°C) in comparison to pure montmorillonite (8.652% at 153.99°C), (Figures 5 and 6). Thermogravimetric analysis curves indicated an increasing in heat stability of the composite. These results seem to indicate that, while the external polymer is destroyed, the inserted polymer retained between the lamellae of the crystallites or between primary particles resists degradation. It appears that the stability of the inserted polymer is due not only its particular structure, but also to the steric factors restricting the thermal motion of the segments sandwiched between the montmorillonite layers. In accordance with the thermal analysis results, the samples were degassed at the temperature of 160°C in order to eliminate the physically bonded water. The nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherms obtained for the initial montmorillonite and the obtained composite are given in Figure 7. Figure 5.
Thermogravimetry (TG), derivative thermogravimetry (DTG) and differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) curves of montmorillonite in nitrogen atmosphere (exo is recorded upward). Figure 6.
Thermogravimetry (TG), derivative thermogravimetry (DTG) and differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) curves in nitrogen atmosphere for obtained composite (exo is recorded upward). Figure 7.
Adsorption–desorption isotherms: montmorillonite and obtained composite based on organically modified montmorillonite and poly(methacrylic acid). PMMA: poly(methylmethacrylate).

The isotherms obtained are type II in International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry (IUPAC) nomenclature, because they are reversible at lower equilibrium pressures, and have a type H3 hysteretic loop at higher equilibrium pressures (p/p0) ≥ 0.4. This type of adsorption–desorption isotherms shows the multilayer adsorption of nitrogen and capillary condensation in mesopores of the porous samples of montmorillonite.31,32 Isotherms type II are characteristic of materials that have plate-shaped particles or particle aggregates. A cluster of lamelles makes up a particle, and the particle consists of parallel lamellas that can be contorted or shifted due to the presence of the polymer. The space between the lamellas, particles and aggregates represent pores of different shapes and sizes. The specific surfaces of the samples, SBET (m2/g), were calculated based on the adsorption measurement data by using data in the range 0.05 < (p/p0) < 0.28.31,32 The total pores volume (V0.99) was calculated according to the Gurvitsch method.27,28 The total micropores volume (Vmic) of the tested samples was determined according to the Dubinin–Radushkevich equation. The pores distribution was determined according to the Dollimore and Heal method32 from the desorption branch of the isotherm. The results obtained for the specific surface, SBET, total pores volume, V0.99. micropores volume, Vmic, and pores diameter, D, are shown in Table 2.

For modified montmorillonite, the specific surface was 52 m2/g and this changed to 19 m2/g in composite samples. In addition, a decreasing in total pore volumes from 0.13 to 0.1 cm3/g and micropore volumes from 0.02 to 0.0007 cm3/g was observed, while the maximum pore diameters did not change significantly and remained at 3.9 nm. It can be concluded that a certain quantity of polymer was deposited on the montmorillonite, which closed the micropores and partially closed the mesopores.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p:
Inorganic–organic host–guest materials based upon layered clay minerals, such as montmorillonite, provide opportunities to investigate novel reactions both on the surface and within the intergallery regions of these clay hosts. In this work the intercalation of the montmorillonite layers was performed using the polymeric macro cation–acid poly(ethylene imine). Based on X-ray measurements, it was estimated that composite materials consist of two forms. In the first, the poly(methacrylic acid) chains were intercalated within the montmorillonite layers, and in the second, they were dispersed in the polymer matrix. In FTIR spectra of the composite material, peaks originating from poly(methacrylic acid) chains were observed. On the other hand, in the diffractograms, there appeared new reflection planes, indicating the polymer intercalation as opposed to unmodified montmorillonite. The obtained adsorption–desorption BET isotherms have a type H3 hysteretic loop at higher equilibrium pressures (p/p0 ≥ 0.4). It was assessed that the specific area of modified montmorillonite specific surface was 52 m2/g, which changed to 19 m2/g in composite material due to the polymer chain intercalation. In addition, a fall of total pore volumes from 0.13 to 0.1 cm3/g and micropore volumes from 0.02 to 0.007 cm3/g was observed, while the maximum diameters of the pores showed no significant changes, and remained at 3.9 nm. It can be concluded that a certain quantity of polymer was deposited on the montmorillonite, closing the micropores and partially closing the mesopores. Table 1.
